prompt: Donald Trump and his White House team have been accused of breaking federal laws by using hidden messaging apps. An ethics watchdog, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, filed a lawsuit against the president and his Executive Office on Thursday alleging they are not acting in compliance with federal records retention laws. 'President Trump and others within the White House are either ignoring or outright flouting these responsibilities,' the suit from CREW states. 'From early on in this Administration, White House staff have used and, on information and belief, continue to use certain email messaging applications that destroy the contents of messages as soon as they are read, without regard to whether the messages are presidential records.' It then cited Trump's controversial Twitter account, which the suit claimed is also legally problematic due to some of the president's posts being deleted. 'Presidential statements made on Twitter sent from the Presidents personal Twitter account, which are subject to federal record-keeping obligations, have been destroyed. 'These actions by the Defendants, which have prevented federal agencies from complying with their statutory responsibilities, violate the constitutional requirement that the President take care that the law be faithfully executed. 'As a further consequence, this regime increases the likelihood that valuable historical records of this presidency are already lost, and will continue to be lost, to Plaintiffs and the public, absent injunctive and declaratory relief.' The suit cites media reports to back up its allegations about Trump's staff using apps such as Signal and Confide to communicate in a more secretive manner. The Washington Postreported in February staffers within the White House were specifically using Confide, an app that immediately destroys messages after the are read. The Wall Street Journal reported in January Trump staffers and associates, including Roger Stone, used Signal. 'This destruction occurs with no independent assessment by the message sender or recipient of whether the message constitutes a presidential record,' the suit states. It then added Trump and his team have 'do not have adequate policies in place' to stop similar deleting apps being used. Internal White House messages and communications must be made available to the public five years after a president leaves office, as per presidential records laws. The National Security Archive at George Washington University joined CREW in the suit. Trump himself has been a vocal critic of politicians deleting messages, as he frequently leveled that allegation against Hillary Clinton during the campaign. Select a headline for the previous text. The options are 'RNLI is the first charity to overhaul its fundraising after investigation revealed unscrupulous tactics', 'Goodbye Daddy: Jonah Lomu's two young sons say farewell to their rugby legend father as he is laid to rest in Auckland', 'Trump and his White House staff are sued for 'breaking federal law by using hidden messaging apps and deleting the president's tweets'', 'Are these the worst waxworks ever? Statues of Trump, Putin and Kim Jong-un are almost unrecognisable as they stand side by side at a Chinese show', 'The Beckhams say adios to Spain: David finally sells Madrid mansion he put on the market EIGHT years ago for £1million profit', 'ITV presenter Susanna Reid calls full time on her relationship with £45m football club owner Steve Parish after a year together… but the pair still team up to watch his side play', 'Royal Marine, 30, accused of Northern Ireland-linked terror offences appears in court over fraud charge'.
completion: Trump and his White House staff are sued for 'breaking federal law by using hidden messaging apps and deleting the president's tweets'

prompt: A man of intellectual refinement. completion: the quality of excellence in thought and manners and taste

Stephen Paddock killed 58 people and wounded more than 500 from room 32-135 at the Mandalay Bay hotel in Las Vegas. Tourist Jeff Bridges took video of the room last year when he stayed there. Paddock spent days inside the room as he prepared to carry out his massacre. He also shot himself dead here after police breached the door with explosives. Is this text about 'news'?

Young adult Horror Book!!I remember reading a book in highschool about a teenage boy caring for his uncle's summer house in the middle of nowhere. There's a specific part that sticks out to me where he goes swimming in the pool and when he comes up from the water he sees a person standing in the doorway by the house but when he goes to check it out he can't find anyone. I'm going crazy trying to figure out what the name of it was!
completion:
Hi there. Maybe you could add a few details that might narrow it down! 
Assume I don’t know (because I don’t lol) what year(s) you were in high school. A range of years if you don’t recall the exact.  Do you remember anything about the cover? Color scheme, etc.? When you read it did it seem dated or more contemporary like it was released at or around the time you read it? 
Thanks! Wait, you're not psychic? Why don't you know when they were in high school?! Lol

When I worked for church IT they specifically told us in orientation that it was all paid via the for-profit/investment ventures of the church and not from tithing. Given lack of transparency and ability to muddy things accounting wise, I really have no idea how to even take what they said.

Is the 6 billion just tithing expenditures, or is it everything excluding their for-profit businesses? As for the for profit companies:

Deseret News - they must be losing money like all other newspapers do. They keep it because it is important for church PR 

KSL probably makes some money

Beneficial Life has been effectively closed. No new sales of insurance for many years. 

DMBA is health insurance for church employees only. 

Agriculture- not huge profits each year. 

Real Estate - profitable

The net profits from these may be part of the $7 B inflows not sure. But I suspect it’s less than $500M per year Interesting, honestly I had always excluded the for profit stuff when thinking about the church’s finances in my head. Certainly their investments in stocks and bonds would be considered “non-operating income/losses”. These can go up and down with the markets but over the long period generally go up.

prompt: My grandpa planted me a tree when I was born. He's passed away, and I want to take cuttings to plant in my yard. How do I do that?
completion: Look on the ol’interwebs on how to make clippings off a tree and how to transplant it. From what I’ve been told you trim a few branches and soak them in water (I’ve been told distilled water is good) and maybe add nutrients until roots sprout.. not 100% sure though and please anyone correct me if I’m wrong. The only thing I’ll say is be careful because the Manitoba Maple (box elder) is very invasive and resilient. So be careful where you plant it because it’ll spread like a wildfire. Prune shoots and keep it contained. It’s not the best tree but I respect the sentimental value of it. I hope one day I can pass on a tree for my family.
They are still considered birds because they have feathers, beaks and many other bird characteristics.
